Princeton, N J, Nov 12— A P—
A revolutionary change in the educational system at Princeton university
was announced today by Edward W
Hobler '39, of Stamford, Connecticut,
chairman of the undergraduate council.
Hobler said a ten man undergraduate committee on academic affairs
with an official voice in determining'
curriculum policies had been formed.
The committee's functions will include criticisms and suggestions regarding courses and individual professors, the forwarding of student opinion on new and old courses of administrative officers, investigation of
various aspects of the curriculum and
the adjustment of examination and
reading period dates.
President Harold W Dodds approved the move, declaring "it is important that the undergraduate feel a
sense of participation in his own education."
Partly responsible for the appointment of the committee, Hobler said,
was recent criticism of Princton's
preceptorial system, which was founded by Woodrow Wilson when he was
the university president in 1902-10.
The Wilson system consisted of the
substitution of small informal rouT-1table discussions with a "faculty preTtor" instead of the usual classes.

The class also voted in favor of
cil as a further method in which to
make the voice of the campus felt.
A minority thought that published
minutes of the council meetings would
be more advisable, believing that open
meetings would hamper the council's
work.
McElhiney declared that he would
be guided by the will of the sophomore class, as expressed at this assembly.
Arrangements for the FreshmanSophomore dance, to be held on December 2 at the Southern hotel, were
also made by the assembly. The time
of the affair was set from 9 to 1, and
semi-formal dress was decided upon.
Opening the assembly, George L
Miller, class president, said:
"We trust that our departure from
established practice will promote a
real spirit and cause each member to
take an active interest in class affairs.
A negative, or even neutral attitude
on the part of the class members will
result in unsatisfactory and mediocre
accomplishment. We want to make
democracy work."

"The Honor commission can look
with pride upon the spread of the
Honor system officially to the College for Teachers," commented Arthur Maas, acting chairman of the
commission.
The extension of the system to the
Teachers college has been something
long desired by the administrators
of the system. Besides furthering the
Honor system theoretically, this step
benefited the students of the Arts
and Business schools who have hitherto been forced to take examinations
on the Teachers college without the
Honor system.
The Student council, last week,
announced the appointment of four
freshmen who are to serve on this
year's commission. They are: C Langdon Harris, John Ratcliffe, Charles
Thomas, and Philip Silverman.
Thus far this year the commission
has been concerned mostly with the
explanation of the Honor system to
the new students.

Ole Man Mose, Annie Laurie, the
Mulberry Bush, Shirley Dewlow, Bob
Craig, and his entire crew turned out
at Latrobe hall Saturday eve to help
Johnny Hopkins celebrate his firSt
Victory dance, but an unforeseen
mishap occurred that afternoon at
Homewood field which sort of threw
a monkey wrench into the plans of
the committee.
It seems as though a bunch of
"double crossers" from Pennsylvania
decided that the "victory" ball should
be postponed for a little longer at
least. However, unthwarted by their
unsociable antics, the fair sized crowd
of Blue Jays went right ahead and
treated themselves to a hot time
pounding away to the smooth rhythm
of Master Craig and his lads. The
presence of Shirley Dewlow did
much to put spirits into the most
downcast of the Hopkins rooters.
Financially, the baby cotillion failed to cause the coffers of the Board
of Social Activities to overrun. Although engineers turned out in larger hordes than ever before, the moguls
and "sport coaters" offset the inPage 4, Please

Bob Craig to play
at Southern hotel
Bringing its plans for a gala FreshJnan-Sophomore dance to a close, the
committee today announced that the
Southern hotel has been chosen for
the occasion on December 2. Tickets
will go on sale in the early part of
next week, announced Thomas McElhiney, who will be in charge of the
sale. The price will be $1.25.
Bob Craig and his orchestra have
been signed to furnish the music for
the dance, which will be in cabaret
style. Shirley Dewlow, locally prominent singer who was enthusiastically
acclaimed at the recent Victory dance,
will be the vocalist.
"If we have the support of both
classes, we can safely expect this to
be one of the greatest class dances
ever given," said Herbert Kleinfield
for the

committee. George Miller,
chairman, and Harry Nance, co-chairman of the committee of twenty,

said that dress will be optional.
The committee is composed of the
officers of the two classes and five
students chosen at large.

declare a vote taken at a class meeting binding on a
Student councilman, it's hardly likely that Councilmen
—even Councilmen who consider petitions unimportant—will vote in opposition to a proposal debated and
decided on in general congress assembled.
Should the Council fail to function by calling an
open assembly on some future issue, the precedent
which this class meeting has set may easily be followed.
A change in custom has resulted in what is to all intents and purposes an amendment to the Student council constitution. And the beautiful part of the whole
thing is that class presidents are much less reluctant
about holding open assemblies than are councilmen
who, once elected, don't have to depend on class support
to make a go of what they propose to do. You couldn't
very well expect a class president who had refused an
open assembly in the face of opposition to get much cooperation for a class dance or banquet. But you could
build up quite a bookie business, it would seem, if you
took bets on what the Council were going to do next,
with or without opposition.
Though the administration has announced that the
issue of the Cotillion board is now ancient history we
feel that history books have not been written for no
purpose, and so we hope that this chapter in the hisory of the Hopkins student government will not pass
unnoticed by those who write the chapters of the future.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1938

This week we print what
amounts to a guest editorial.
Seekers after truth can find
it on page 1, column 3. It
describes the new system
under which students at
Princeton university are
given nearly complete autonomy in their own affairs.
The moral of this story is too obvious to need laboring here.
Princeton undergraduates are reported to have complained for more than twenty years before they had
their way. But, what heartens us at this time, is not the
difficulties of their struggle, but their final victory.
The fight for democracy is not an easy one. It is
a long-drawn out and sometimes tedious effort. There
is no room in it for summer soldiers.
The Princeton case holds many lessons for us. The
most obvious is that a great university can afford to
give its students control over their own affairs..
Bu there is a greater lesson in all this. For we cannot escape the conclusion that time is on our side.
Princeton waited two decades for justice to triumph.
The fight was an arduous one, but it ended in victory.
Most good fights finally wind up that way.

We hope we don't insult
your intelligence by reminding you that a short
time ago there appeared in
these columns a question:
Do we get self-government
or don't we?
Yesterday something took place that helps us to
arrive at an answer to that query. The sophomore
class had a meeting, which, we think, was a democratic
meeting; democratic because it was run by the class
members, not by the class officers.
The train of discussion at the meeting (which we
are told is the first if its kind at the Hopkins) was
divided into two veins. The first was concerned with
the freshman-sophomore dance, soon to be held; the
sophomores gave thir viewpoints, most frankly and
shaped plans to as large an extent as possible.
But it is with the second vein of discussion that we
are primarily concerned. The result of this discussion
was a resolution that "we, of the sophomore class, are
in favor of open assemblies to debate and decide openly
matters such as the Cotillion board purge." It, too, was
a unanimous result.
When a representative body is asked an opinion
by its leaders we are definitely approaching a spirit
of government that is democratic. This action means
that the representatives of the sophomore class are
really the representatives of the sophomore class. At
present it appears that the sophomore class is setting a
bit of precedent.
The sophomore meeting presents another point. One
of the objections of students both on and off the Colin.
cil to open assemblies has been that they present an
opportunity for heckling and time-wasting discussion.
The sophomore meeting had such discussion and (with
apologies to the sophomores) the members at that
meeting certainly had little previous experience by
which they might guide themselves in the conduct of an
open meeting.
Implications of the meeting are even more important than the meeting itself. By using it to discuss more
than dance arrangements, the sophomore class officers
have placed an instrument of power in the hands of
those who previously have been forced to petition and
more than likely have their petitions refused. Although
the fact still remains that class officers have no right to

By Sidney Piness
At this time of year, since the bigtime bands are making their best recordings, and since it looks as if there
may not be any dancing or swinging
on this campus- for a while, a column
devoted to swing, Swing, and more
SWING seems to be in order. That
mid-semester gloom accompanied by
that "women-are-dopes-they-live-inhopes-when -will - they-ever-learn-the
ropes" attitude should be swept away
with a couple of blasts from Artie
Shaw's clarinet or perhaps with one
long slide by Brother Dorsey's trombone.
At any rate, things have been happening so rapidly in the world of wax
that before we look around, we see
that there are two more bands up in
the sky, already sparkling with name
bands. They are Artie Shaw and Jan
Savitt, and these boys and their respective bands are really out of this
world!
If we were to have a Hall of Fame
(and why not have one?), Artie
Shaw would definitely be skyrocketed
up there tout de suite. All this proShavian propaganda is due to three
solid platters which are fit to leave
one breathless. They are "Begin the
Beguine" with "Indian Love Call" on
the reverse side, "What is this Thing
called Love" backed by "Yesterdays",
and "Nightmare" teamed with "NonStop Flight." "The Beguine" and
"What is this Thing Called Love"
are definitely the two finest releases
this band has ever made, and that
says a lot, considering Artie's past
record. But, no wonder, since Mister
S's licorice stick which is plenty
solid in itself, is backed up by that
Incomparable rhythm section. Quite
a powerhouse!
While

Mister

Shaw

has

been

scratching the wax over at Victor,
another threat, in the form of Jan
Savitt and his Top Hatters, has been
climbing rapidly to the heights of
popularity. Jan features the famous
"Shuffle Rhythm" and his recordings
are greatly enhanced by his two excellent vocalists, Bon Bon and Carlotta Dale. Among the better platters
by Savitt are "You Go To my Head"
backed by "Tootie Fruitie" and "Ya
Got Me" from the University of Pennsylvania Mask and Wig show. Should
any of you happen to be in Philadelphia for the Penn-Cornell game or
at any other time, you may dance to
Jan Savitt at the famous Arcadia.
We're told the joint's jumpin'.
As for the other top-flight bands,
they have certainly outdone themselves in recording hits this month.
Among these, Hal Kemp and Skinny
Ennis have recorded two pieces which
are faintly reminiscent of the old
Kemp. They are "Monday Morning",
"Bambino" (Kemp), and "Deep in a
• Dream" and "Gardenias" (Ennis)
Benny Goodman has also released
an album of eight songs, seven of
which are classic standards in the
repetoire of swing. These recordings
include "Sweet Sue", "Sweet Georgia Brown", "Blue Room" and others
Larry Clinton's "Chant of the Jungle", "Design for Dancing", and Tommy Dorsey's "Down Home Rag" and
"A Room With a View", with vocal
by Jack Leonard, are also among the
new releases showing promise.
Since this column -may become a
permanent feature, please send in
any suggestions you may have as to
a more appropriate title or a better
column. Drop a note in Box 841 (that
will be our stomping ground, or at
least our new home for the present,
despite its size.)

Jay boaters meet Maryland in quest of title
Title looms
on outcome
of Terp battle
Coach Bobby Lyon's lads, inspired
after a thrilling victory over last
year's tottering state champs, are
drilling diligently for their all-important meeting with the University of
Maryland booters scheduled for Tuesday at College park.
So far, the Terp soccer record
hasn't been too impressive, having
lost games to Virginia and Towson
State Teachers. Incidentally, the
Teachers won over Maryland in grand
fashion via the shut out route 3-0.

The College park team is built around a few stars. The team has been
moulded around Todd, center forward,
Fanner, outside left, and Schroeder,
inside right. There are three bulwarks
of defense in fullbacks, Mears, Dougherty, and the star goalie Jim Maisel.
Last year the Terrapins defeated
the Jay booters in a closely contested
game 2-1, on the College park field.
Maryland would like to repeat this
year, but the Lyonsmen have hit
their peak and are now hard to stop.
A victory for Hopkins would place
it in a tie with Towson State Teachers for honors in the Maryland Intercollegiate Soccer league. Then a
second Towson-Hopkins match would
have to be played in order to determine the State champs for the '38
season.
Only one casualty bobbed up after
the Western Md. fray and that was a
leg injury sustained by the Hopkins
star goalie, Frank Butt. It is believed
• that he will be in shape for the Maryland contest; if not, there is Milt Alperstein to tend the Hopkins goal.
If goalie Butt's leg responds favorably to treatment, the spirited Jay
booters will take the field Tuesday
with Eser, Hobbs, Briggs, Bra.yshaw,
and Gwynn on the line; Hoopes, Six,
and Salvia at the midfield posts; Stout
and Andrus holding down the fullback
assignments, and Frank Butt protecting the Blue team's goal. In reserve
will be Dertzbaugh, and Dunlop, linemen; Wiese, Diehl, Shawker, and
Cummiskey, backfield men; Alperstein and Zerevitz, goalies.
Up to date, the Lyonsmen have defeated Gettysburg 3-2, Blue Ridge
twice 3-0 and 3-2, and Western Md.
4-3. They have tied Virginia and Towson in scoreless games and have lost
to West Point 3-0. The cry now heard
is to beat Maryland for another shot
at Towson.

Harriers Top
HaverFord 27-28
Last Saturday, Homewood field
looked like a three-ring circus. A
soccer game was in full swing on the
lower field and a football battle was
going at full blast in the stadium. At
the half of the football game the
cross-country men entered the stadium through the north gate on their
final sprint to break the tape. John
Driscoll appeared first and the crowd
was astonished by the fact that there
was no Haverford man in close pursuit. Driscoll had almost finished his
lap around the track when a Haverford runner finally appeared. ,
Driscoll finished the four-mile
course 300 yards ahead of Haverford. His time was 23.23. Nice work!
Haverford placed second and third.
The Hopkins harriers, Jeffers and
Heuther, placed fourth and fifth, reRatcliffe
and
Lewis
spectively.
placed eight and ninth. These boys
are trying hard and they are showing great improvement in their endurance. The final score was 27-28.
Next week, the harriers will again
enter the stadium during the half
of the J H U-American game, only
this time they will be fighting the
boys from Gettysburg.
The prophesy for the Gettysburg
meet seems to be much brighter than
last week. The only comment that
Johnny Driscoll would make was,
"Haverford beat Gettysburg." Only
a few words, but they mean a whole
lot. Besides this tense bit of information, all the runners appear to be
improving.

Lyons men topple
state champs 4-3
Last Saturday, the Blue soccer
team managed to win one of the
most thrilling games ever played on
the Homewood field. It was a nipand-tuck battle from beginning to
end. Hopkins finally topped W Mary.
land 4-3.
The Terrors, last year's state
champs, scored immediately after the
opening whistle when Wallace drove
one into the goal after taking a
pass from Elias. Then the Blue team
bounced back and Briggs scored after some beautiful passwork by
Hobbs and Brayshaw.
The lads from Westminster rallied
at the ending of the first quarter
when Wallace again chalked up another marker, this time taking a pass
from Applegarth. The second quarter saw both teams playing great
defensive ball. The haff ended with
Western Md leading 2-1.
The Jay forward wall, on some
shifty manuvering set the ball up
for Briggs who registered his second
goal. This started off the fireworks,
for the Terrors rebounded and
scored when Tomlinson, using his
stomach, directed a pass into the
goal. The score rested at 3-2 in favor of Coach Wright's men.
The score didn't remain that way
for long, because Hobbs drove the
leather past Goalie Dooley to knot
up the ball game. In the fourth quarter Wallace failed to score on a
penalty shot after Salvia had
touched the ball with his hands. The
fourth quarter and the game ended
3-3.
Both coaches decided on overtime
play lasting for ten minutes. Brayshaw scored the winning goal in the
second minute of the first five minutes overtime period. The remaining
eight minutes of play were domi.
nated by the inspired Hopkins' booters who put on a fine exhibition of
air-tight defense with Andrus, Stout,
and Butt as the stalwarts.

Last minute
Fre results
E T A furthered her fight for the
league "A" interfraternity football
championship when they downed a
fighting D U team yesterday, 12-0.
E T A scored after three minutes
of play on a pass from Milberg to
Schwartzman, after Checkett had
paved the way for the touchdown
on a pass interception. Their second
touchdown came late in the second
half when Moss speared Milberg's
pass over the goal which completed
a 50-yard touchdown march.
DU threatened the ETA goal several times as they came within the
five-yard line, but fifth down passes
failed, and ETA took possession of
the ball.

Interclass touch league
nearing its end
This week brings to a close the
1938 interclass touch football league.
Looking over the standings one notices that only one team remains
undefeated in the season play showing that the teams were evenly
matched and no team had a cinch in
its league. It is worth mentioning
here that the spirit of the men particularly has been unequaled in the
history of the interclass competition.
Last, but surely not least, we should
not fail to mention the fine work
done by the genial Mr Baer in arranging the schedules, and in the
spirit he has aroused in the different
teams.
The first game of the week ended
In a tie between the Sophomore
Business and the Bab Playboys,
necessitating a play-off game to determine the league champ. The Playboys, were the first to score. Taking
the ball deep in their own territory,
the Babs advanced close to the
Sophs goal when McCord, on a well
executed reverse, carried the ball over
for the six points. The second year
men came back fighting but always
failed to click when it was needed
most, and the remainder of the first
half saw neither team do any further
scoring.
After half-time, the Business Men
came back and scored on an end
sweep, with Eager carrying the ball.
Coming back in a few minutes, the
Sophs added another goal when
Agnew passed to Fehr on the 10, and
the latter scampered over the white
line. Not to be outdone, the Bab
Playboys renewed their first half
offensive and scored. This time
Schreive plunged through center for
the touchdown. Throughout the remainder of the game neither team
made any serious threats and the

final score was 12.12. The playoff
game between these two teams will
be played sometime this week convenient to both sides.
By virtue of their win over the
Wednesday A B, the Tech Hawks
became champs of the Wednesday
league. As in all thir previous games,
the Tech Hawks smothered their opposition. This time they won 26-0
over the Wednesday team. The
Hawks aerial and running attack
was a constant source of trouble to
the Wednesday team. The Hawks
seemed to be able to score whenever
they cared to. Scoring for the Hawks
was done by Diggs, who accounted
for 12 points, Ross 6, Holby 6, and
Edmunds scored 2 points on a safety.
The Techs enter the playoff games
to be played the latter part of this
week.
In the final game of the day the
Senior Engineers won by a forfeit
over the Senior Civils.
The Soph A met the Frosh A in
the first game on Thursday. The
Sophs by virtue of this victory won
the honors in their league. Scoring
first, early in the first period, were
the Frosh. Besche on a series of end
runs and reverses carried the ball
over the goal line. The Sophs came
back quickly and scored twice in
quick succession, once by Gray and
once by Eager. In the second half the
sophomores were contented in protecting their lead and were able to
prevent the Frosh from doing any
further scoring. The final score being
12-6. The last game of the week was
between the Library and the Cement
Mixers which was won by the Library 12-6.
The Sophomore Mechanic Elects
clinched the honors in the Friday
league last week.

Eta footballers top Phi Gam
Pi Lam sets new record
In one of the best football games
of the year, E T A came from the
short end of an 8-6 score at the half
to hand Phi Gam their first defeat
of the season, 18-8. It was the fifth
straight victory for the ETA's, while
it was the first loss in five starts for
Phi Gam.
E T A scored first on a fourth down
pass from Milberg to Checkett, which
counted for 25 yards and the score.
The Phi Gams were not to be out
done, however, and they quickly knotted the score. After working the ball
down the field on four plays, the Phi
Gams sent Shorty Cross over the
goal line and the whole E T A defense hopped on Shorty; but he served only as a decoy on this play as
Kenney was way out in the flat waiting for the pass from Tosch and he
scored easily. A few minutes later
Milberg was touched behind his own
goal line for a safety, and Phi Gam
led 8-6 as the half ended.
E T A got right back in the ball
game on the kickoff of the second
half when Checkett whipped a 50
yard pass to Erskine, and the latter
was touched on the 2 yard line. E T
A made the score 12-8 two plays later
when Rossett passed to Milberg for
the score.
Phi Gam threatened several times,
but the E T A defense stiffened at
crucial moments, and latter sewed up
the ball game on a pass from Milberg
to Tannenbaum for the third touchdown.
In a rather mild upset Phi Sig defeated a hitherto undefeated Kappa
Sig team 12-6.

Taking an active part in the youth
section, the Johns Hopkins university was represented at the Foreign
Relations conference last week by
Dr Isaiah Bowman and members of
the American Student union.
,Sponsored by the Maryland Peace
conference, the meetings were initiated last Friday at Mount Vernon
place M E church when Dr Bowman
led a general discussion. It was terminated at a concluding session on
Sunday with Dr John Harms, Executive Secretary of the Council of
Churches and Christian Education,
presiding.
Rosa Swindell, a student in the
College for Teachers and representative of the ASU, was selected to the
executive committee of the Conference at Sunday's final session.
"I should like to thank President
Bowman and the Hopkins representatives for taking such a very active
part in the meetings," declared Ken
Cuthbertson, executive secretary of
the Maryland Peace conference.
The meetings were terminated with
the passage of eight resolutions. They
were:
1. To express the thanks of the conference to President Roosevelt, secretary of state Hull and others who
took an active interest in the foreign
refugee problem.
2. To call to the attention of authorities the resources available for
European refugees in this country.
3. To condemn Germany's policy
of religious persecution.
4. To oppose increased armament
programs as unwarranted by the present international situation.
5. To appoint a committee to investigate and act on relief problems
in Spain and China.
6. To favor an arms embargo on
aggressive nations.
7. To recommend that the state department not collect private debts
in Mexico and adhere strictly to the
good neighbor policy.
8. To oppose industrial mobilization
plans.
Representation at the conference
was divided into three groups—general, youth, and labor sctions. A significant factor of the conference membership was the larger than usual representation from labor groups.

Princeton, N J, Nov 12— A P—
A revolutionary change in the educational system at Princeton university
was announced today by Edward W
Hobler '39, of Stamford, Connecticut,
chairman of the undergraduate council.
Hobler said a ten man undergraduate committee on academic affairs
with an official voice in determining'
curriculum policies had been formed.
The committee's functions will include criticisms and suggestions regarding courses and individual professors, the forwarding of student opinion on new and old courses of administrative officers, investigation of
various aspects of the curriculum and
the adjustment of examination and
reading period dates.
President Harold W Dodds approved the move, declaring "it is important that the undergraduate feel a
sense of participation in his own education."
Partly responsible for the appointment of the committee, Hobler said,
was recent criticism of Princton's
preceptorial system, which was founded by Woodrow Wilson when he was
the university president in 1902-10.
The Wilson system consisted of the
substitution of small informal rouT-1table discussions with a "faculty preTtor" instead of the usual classes.

"The Honor commission can look
with pride upon the spread of the
Honor system officially to the College for Teachers," commented Arthur Maas, acting chairman of the
commission.
The extension of the system to the
Teachers college has been something
long desired by the administrators
of the system. Besides furthering the
Honor system theoretically, this step
benefited the students of the Arts
and Business schools who have hitherto been forced to take examinations
on the Teachers college without the
Honor system.
The Student council, last week,
announced the appointment of four
freshmen who are to serve on this
year's commission. They are: C Langdon Harris, John Ratcliffe, Charles
Thomas, and Philip Silverman.
Thus far this year the commission
has been concerned mostly with the
explanation of the Honor system to
the new students.

Bringing its plans for a gala FreshJnan-Sophomore dance to a close, the
committee today announced that the
Southern hotel has been chosen for
the occasion on December 2. Tickets
will go on sale in the early part of
next week, announced Thomas McElhiney, who will be in charge of the

Bob Craig and his orchestra have
been signed to furnish the music for

style. Shirley Dewlow, locally prominent singer who was enthusiastically

will be the vocalist.

classes, we can safely expect this to
be one of the greatest class dances
ever given," said Herbert Kleinfield
for the

committee. George Miller,
chairman, and Harry Nance, co-chairman of the committee of twenty,

officers of the two classes and five
students chosen at large.

Student councilman, it's hardly likely that Councilmen
—even Councilmen who consider petitions unimportant—will vote in opposition to a proposal debated and
decided on in general congress assembled.
Should the Council fail to function by calling an
open assembly on some future issue, the precedent
which this class meeting has set may easily be followed.
A change in custom has resulted in what is to all intents and purposes an amendment to the Student council constitution. And the beautiful part of the whole
thing is that class presidents are much less reluctant
about holding open assemblies than are councilmen
who, once elected, don't have to depend on class support
to make a go of what they propose to do. You couldn't
very well expect a class president who had refused an
open assembly in the face of opposition to get much cooperation for a class dance or banquet. But you could
build up quite a bookie business, it would seem, if you
took bets on what the Council were going to do next,
with or without opposition.
Though the administration has announced that the
issue of the Cotillion board is now ancient history we
feel that history books have not been written for no
purpose, and so we hope that this chapter in the hisory of the Hopkins student government will not pass
unnoticed by those who write the chapters of the future.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1938

This week we print what
amounts to a guest editorial.
Seekers after truth can find
it on page 1, column 3. It
describes the new system
under which students at
Princeton university are
given nearly complete autonomy in their own affairs.
The moral of this story is too obvious to need laboring here.
Princeton undergraduates are reported to have complained for more than twenty years before they had
their way. But, what heartens us at this time, is not the
difficulties of their struggle, but their final victory.
The fight for democracy is not an easy one. It is
a long-drawn out and sometimes tedious effort. There
is no room in it for summer soldiers.
The Princeton case holds many lessons for us. The
most obvious is that a great university can afford to
give its students control over their own affairs..
Bu there is a greater lesson in all this. For we cannot escape the conclusion that time is on our side.
Princeton waited two decades for justice to triumph.
The fight was an arduous one, but it ended in victory.
Most good fights finally wind up that way.

We hope we don't insult
your intelligence by reminding you that a short
time ago there appeared in
these columns a question:
Do we get self-government
or don't we?
Yesterday something took place that helps us to
arrive at an answer to that query. The sophomore
class had a meeting, which, we think, was a democratic
meeting; democratic because it was run by the class
members, not by the class officers.
The train of discussion at the meeting (which we
are told is the first if its kind at the Hopkins) was
divided into two veins. The first was concerned with
the freshman-sophomore dance, soon to be held; the
sophomores gave thir viewpoints, most frankly and
shaped plans to as large an extent as possible.
But it is with the second vein of discussion that we
are primarily concerned. The result of this discussion
was a resolution that "we, of the sophomore class, are
in favor of open assemblies to debate and decide openly
matters such as the Cotillion board purge." It, too, was
a unanimous result.
When a representative body is asked an opinion
by its leaders we are definitely approaching a spirit
of government that is democratic. This action means
that the representatives of the sophomore class are
really the representatives of the sophomore class. At
present it appears that the sophomore class is setting a
bit of precedent.
The sophomore meeting presents another point. One
of the objections of students both on and off the Colin.
cil to open assemblies has been that they present an
opportunity for heckling and time-wasting discussion.
The sophomore meeting had such discussion and (with
apologies to the sophomores) the members at that
meeting certainly had little previous experience by
which they might guide themselves in the conduct of an
open meeting.
Implications of the meeting are even more important than the meeting itself. By using it to discuss more
than dance arrangements, the sophomore class officers
have placed an instrument of power in the hands of
those who previously have been forced to petition and
more than likely have their petitions refused. Although
the fact still remains that class officers have no right to

By Sidney Piness
At this time of year, since the bigtime bands are making their best recordings, and since it looks as if there
may not be any dancing or swinging
on this campus- for a while, a column
devoted to swing, Swing, and more
SWING seems to be in order. That
mid-semester gloom accompanied by
that "women-are-dopes-they-live-inhopes-when -will - they-ever-learn-the
ropes" attitude should be swept away
with a couple of blasts from Artie
Shaw's clarinet or perhaps with one
long slide by Brother Dorsey's trombone.
At any rate, things have been happening so rapidly in the world of wax
that before we look around, we see
that there are two more bands up in
the sky, already sparkling with name
bands. They are Artie Shaw and Jan
Savitt, and these boys and their respective bands are really out of this
world!
If we were to have a Hall of Fame
(and why not have one?), Artie
Shaw would definitely be skyrocketed
up there tout de suite. All this proShavian propaganda is due to three
solid platters which are fit to leave
one breathless. They are "Begin the
Beguine" with "Indian Love Call" on
the reverse side, "What is this Thing
called Love" backed by "Yesterdays",
and "Nightmare" teamed with "NonStop Flight." "The Beguine" and
"What is this Thing Called Love"
are definitely the two finest releases
this band has ever made, and that
says a lot, considering Artie's past
record. But, no wonder, since Mister
S's licorice stick which is plenty
solid in itself, is backed up by that
Incomparable rhythm section. Quite
a powerhouse!
While

Mister

Shaw

has

been

scratching the wax over at Victor,
another threat, in the form of Jan
Savitt and his Top Hatters, has been
climbing rapidly to the heights of
popularity. Jan features the famous
"Shuffle Rhythm" and his recordings
are greatly enhanced by his two excellent vocalists, Bon Bon and Carlotta Dale. Among the better platters
by Savitt are "You Go To my Head"
backed by "Tootie Fruitie" and "Ya
Got Me" from the University of Pennsylvania Mask and Wig show. Should
any of you happen to be in Philadelphia for the Penn-Cornell game or
at any other time, you may dance to
Jan Savitt at the famous Arcadia.
We're told the joint's jumpin'.
As for the other top-flight bands,
they have certainly outdone themselves in recording hits this month.
Among these, Hal Kemp and Skinny
Ennis have recorded two pieces which
are faintly reminiscent of the old
Kemp. They are "Monday Morning",
"Bambino" (Kemp), and "Deep in a
• Dream" and "Gardenias" (Ennis)
Benny Goodman has also released
an album of eight songs, seven of
which are classic standards in the
repetoire of swing. These recordings
include "Sweet Sue", "Sweet Georgia Brown", "Blue Room" and others
Larry Clinton's "Chant of the Jungle", "Design for Dancing", and Tommy Dorsey's "Down Home Rag" and
"A Room With a View", with vocal
by Jack Leonard, are also among the
new releases showing promise.
Since this column -may become a
permanent feature, please send in
any suggestions you may have as to
a more appropriate title or a better
column. Drop a note in Box 841 (that
will be our stomping ground, or at
least our new home for the present,
despite its size.)

Coach Bobby Lyon's lads, inspired

So far, the Terp soccer record

lost games to Virginia and Towson
State Teachers. Incidentally, the
Teachers won over Maryland in grand
fashion via the shut out route 3-0.

The College park team is built around a few stars. The team has been
moulded around Todd, center forward,
Fanner, outside left, and Schroeder,
inside right. There are three bulwarks
of defense in fullbacks, Mears, Dougherty, and the star goalie Jim Maisel.
Last year the Terrapins defeated
the Jay booters in a closely contested
game 2-1, on the College park field.
Maryland would like to repeat this
year, but the Lyonsmen have hit
their peak and are now hard to stop.
A victory for Hopkins would place
it in a tie with Towson State Teachers for honors in the Maryland Intercollegiate Soccer league. Then a
second Towson-Hopkins match would
have to be played in order to determine the State champs for the '38
season.
Only one casualty bobbed up after
the Western Md. fray and that was a
leg injury sustained by the Hopkins
star goalie, Frank Butt. It is believed
• that he will be in shape for the Maryland contest; if not, there is Milt Alperstein to tend the Hopkins goal.
If goalie Butt's leg responds favorably to treatment, the spirited Jay
booters will take the field Tuesday
with Eser, Hobbs, Briggs, Bra.yshaw,
and Gwynn on the line; Hoopes, Six,
and Salvia at the midfield posts; Stout
and Andrus holding down the fullback
assignments, and Frank Butt protecting the Blue team's goal. In reserve
will be Dertzbaugh, and Dunlop, linemen; Wiese, Diehl, Shawker, and
Cummiskey, backfield men; Alperstein and Zerevitz, goalies.
Up to date, the Lyonsmen have defeated Gettysburg 3-2, Blue Ridge
twice 3-0 and 3-2, and Western Md.
4-3. They have tied Virginia and Towson in scoreless games and have lost
to West Point 3-0. The cry now heard
is to beat Maryland for another shot
at Towson.

Harriers Top
HaverFord 27-28
Last Saturday, Homewood field
looked like a three-ring circus. A
soccer game was in full swing on the
lower field and a football battle was
going at full blast in the stadium. At
the half of the football game the
cross-country men entered the stadium through the north gate on their
final sprint to break the tape. John
Driscoll appeared first and the crowd
was astonished by the fact that there
was no Haverford man in close pursuit. Driscoll had almost finished his
lap around the track when a Haverford runner finally appeared. ,
Driscoll finished the four-mile
course 300 yards ahead of Haverford. His time was 23.23. Nice work!
Haverford placed second and third.
The Hopkins harriers, Jeffers and
Heuther, placed fourth and fifth, reRatcliffe
and
Lewis
spectively.
placed eight and ninth. These boys
are trying hard and they are showing great improvement in their endurance. The final score was 27-28.
Next week, the harriers will again
enter the stadium during the half
of the J H U-American game, only
this time they will be fighting the
boys from Gettysburg.
The prophesy for the Gettysburg
meet seems to be much brighter than
last week. The only comment that
Johnny Driscoll would make was,
"Haverford beat Gettysburg." Only
a few words, but they mean a whole
lot. Besides this tense bit of information, all the runners appear to be
improving.

Lyons men topple
state champs 4-3
Last Saturday, the Blue soccer
team managed to win one of the
most thrilling games ever played on
the Homewood field. It was a nipand-tuck battle from beginning to
end. Hopkins finally topped W Mary.
land 4-3.
The Terrors, last year's state
champs, scored immediately after the
opening whistle when Wallace drove
one into the goal after taking a
pass from Elias. Then the Blue team
bounced back and Briggs scored after some beautiful passwork by
Hobbs and Brayshaw.
The lads from Westminster rallied
at the ending of the first quarter
when Wallace again chalked up another marker, this time taking a pass
from Applegarth. The second quarter saw both teams playing great
defensive ball. The haff ended with
Western Md leading 2-1.
The Jay forward wall, on some
shifty manuvering set the ball up
for Briggs who registered his second
goal. This started off the fireworks,
for the Terrors rebounded and
scored when Tomlinson, using his
stomach, directed a pass into the
goal. The score rested at 3-2 in favor of Coach Wright's men.
The score didn't remain that way
for long, because Hobbs drove the
leather past Goalie Dooley to knot
up the ball game. In the fourth quarter Wallace failed to score on a
penalty shot after Salvia had
touched the ball with his hands. The
fourth quarter and the game ended
3-3.
Both coaches decided on overtime
play lasting for ten minutes. Brayshaw scored the winning goal in the
second minute of the first five minutes overtime period. The remaining
eight minutes of play were domi.
nated by the inspired Hopkins' booters who put on a fine exhibition of
air-tight defense with Andrus, Stout,
and Butt as the stalwarts.

E T A furthered her fight for the
league "A" interfraternity football
championship when they downed a
fighting D U team yesterday, 12-0.
E T A scored after three minutes
of play on a pass from Milberg to
Schwartzman, after Checkett had
paved the way for the touchdown
on a pass interception. Their second
touchdown came late in the second
half when Moss speared Milberg's

DU threatened the ETA goal several times as they came within the
five-yard line, but fifth down passes
failed, and ETA took possession of

DUKE UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
DURHAM, N. C.
Four terms of eleven weeks are given
each year. These may be taken consecutively (graduation in three and
one-quarter years) or three terms
may be taken each year (gradua
tion in four years). The entrance
requirements are intelligence, character and three years of college
work, including the subjects specified for Class A medical schools.
Catalogues and application forms
may be obtained from the Admission Committee.

Interclass touch league
nearing its end
This week brings to a close the
1938 interclass touch football league.
Looking over the standings one notices that only one team remains
undefeated in the season play showing that the teams were evenly
matched and no team had a cinch in
its league. It is worth mentioning
here that the spirit of the men particularly has been unequaled in the
history of the interclass competition.
Last, but surely not least, we should
not fail to mention the fine work
done by the genial Mr Baer in arranging the schedules, and in the
spirit he has aroused in the different
teams.
The first game of the week ended
In a tie between the Sophomore
Business and the Bab Playboys,
necessitating a play-off game to determine the league champ. The Playboys, were the first to score. Taking
the ball deep in their own territory,
the Babs advanced close to the
Sophs goal when McCord, on a well
executed reverse, carried the ball over
for the six points. The second year
men came back fighting but always
failed to click when it was needed
most, and the remainder of the first
half saw neither team do any further
scoring.
After half-time, the Business Men
came back and scored on an end
sweep, with Eager carrying the ball.
Coming back in a few minutes, the
Sophs added another goal when
Agnew passed to Fehr on the 10, and
the latter scampered over the white
line. Not to be outdone, the Bab
Playboys renewed their first half
offensive and scored. This time
Schreive plunged through center for
the touchdown. Throughout the remainder of the game neither team
made any serious threats and the

final score was 12.12. The playoff
game between these two teams will
be played sometime this week convenient to both sides.
By virtue of their win over the
Wednesday A B, the Tech Hawks
became champs of the Wednesday
league. As in all thir previous games,
the Tech Hawks smothered their opposition. This time they won 26-0
over the Wednesday team. The
Hawks aerial and running attack
was a constant source of trouble to
the Wednesday team. The Hawks
seemed to be able to score whenever
they cared to. Scoring for the Hawks
was done by Diggs, who accounted
for 12 points, Ross 6, Holby 6, and
Edmunds scored 2 points on a safety.
The Techs enter the playoff games
to be played the latter part of this
week.
In the final game of the day the
Senior Engineers won by a forfeit
over the Senior Civils.
The Soph A met the Frosh A in
the first game on Thursday. The
Sophs by virtue of this victory won
the honors in their league. Scoring
first, early in the first period, were
the Frosh. Besche on a series of end
runs and reverses carried the ball
over the goal line. The Sophs came
back quickly and scored twice in
quick succession, once by Gray and
once by Eager. In the second half the
sophomores were contented in protecting their lead and were able to
prevent the Frosh from doing any
further scoring. The final score being
12-6. The last game of the week was
between the Library and the Cement
Mixers which was won by the Library 12-6.
The Sophomore Mechanic Elects
clinched the honors in the Friday
league last week.

Eta footballers top Phi Gam
Pi Lam sets new record
In one of the best football games
of the year, E T A came from the
short end of an 8-6 score at the half
to hand Phi Gam their first defeat
of the season, 18-8. It was the fifth
straight victory for the ETA's, while
it was the first loss in five starts for
Phi Gam.
E T A scored first on a fourth down
pass from Milberg to Checkett, which
counted for 25 yards and the score.
The Phi Gams were not to be out
done, however, and they quickly knotted the score. After working the ball
down the field on four plays, the Phi
Gams sent Shorty Cross over the
goal line and the whole E T A defense hopped on Shorty; but he served only as a decoy on this play as
Kenney was way out in the flat waiting for the pass from Tosch and he
scored easily. A few minutes later
Milberg was touched behind his own
goal line for a safety, and Phi Gam
led 8-6 as the half ended.
E T A got right back in the ball
game on the kickoff of the second
half when Checkett whipped a 50
yard pass to Erskine, and the latter
was touched on the 2 yard line. E T
A made the score 12-8 two plays later
when Rossett passed to Milberg for
the score.
Phi Gam threatened several times,
but the E T A defense stiffened at
crucial moments, and latter sewed up
the ball game on a pass from Milberg
to Tannenbaum for the third touchdown.
In a rather mild upset Phi Sig defeated a hitherto undefeated Kappa
Sig team 12-6.

JHU

represented
at Peace confab
by Bowman, ASU

Taking an active part in the youth
section, the Johns Hopkins university was represented at the Foreign
Relations conference last week by
Dr Isaiah Bowman and members of
the American Student union.
,Sponsored by the Maryland Peace
conference, the meetings were initiated last Friday at Mount Vernon
place M E church when Dr Bowman
led a general discussion. It was terminated at a concluding session on
Sunday with Dr John Harms, Executive Secretary of the Council of
Churches and Christian Education,
presiding.
Rosa Swindell, a student in the
College for Teachers and representative of the ASU, was selected to the
executive committee of the Conference at Sunday's final session.
"I should like to thank President
Bowman and the Hopkins representatives for taking such a very active
part in the meetings," declared Ken
Cuthbertson, executive secretary of
the Maryland Peace conference.
The meetings were terminated with
the passage of eight resolutions. They
were:
1. To express the thanks of the conference to President Roosevelt, secretary of state Hull and others who
took an active interest in the foreign
refugee problem.
2. To call to the attention of authorities the resources available for
European refugees in this country.
3. To condemn Germany's policy
of religious persecution.
4. To oppose increased armament
programs as unwarranted by the present international situation.
5. To appoint a committee to investigate and act on relief problems
in Spain and China.
6. To favor an arms embargo on
aggressive nations.
7. To recommend that the state department not collect private debts
in Mexico and adhere strictly to the
good neighbor policy.
8. To oppose industrial mobilization
plans.
Representation at the conference
was divided into three groups—general, youth, and labor sctions. A significant factor of the conference membership was the larger than usual representation from labor groups.
